comments.commentBody: All my posts will contain hiddeN messages  frOm noW on, starting todAY...  On a more serious note - Patrick is very funny this week!
All my posts will contain hiddeN messages  frOm noW on, starting todAY...  On a more serious note - Patrick is very funny this week!
The puzzle and comments may be very clever, but I'm taking my talents to South Beach.
The puzzle and comments may be very clever, but I'm taking my talents to South Beach.

Eggs! Place 3 eggs evenly separated on a microwave turn-table and microwave for a few seconds (not too long or they will explode). Notice how all 3 eggs will frequently roll together so they are touching...

And gravity I think is just a synergistic effect of LARGE collection of eggs or mass/dirt/whatever. Density matters.

If this is true, then if you were next to a very large mountain and had a very sensitive gravity measuring device, then there would be a bit of "sideways pull" toward that mountain. And I should think a more dense or thicker mountain would have more sideways pull.

This work represents another "area of study", not precise enough to make a prediction.
I have a unified standard model hypothesis that makes predictions different from GR. Gravity is literally a force of "universal love" where all particles no matter their subparticles attract. Tests of the equivalence principle fall into this category. One needs math that only knows one kind of sign, 100% positive signs throughout, so it cannot toss in a minus sign and have repulsion. Now one does need a fancy education to understand how the Lagrange density leads to the field equations. Those field equations have every term that appears in the linear field equations for GR, but three of the signs are different. And yes, it all fits on a t-shirt like the Maxwell equations (http://bit.ly/GEMtshirt)
The metric that solves the field equations predicts a wee little bit more bending of light as it passes by the Sun than does GR. The precision will need to be improved by 100-1000 to know if my work or GR is right, but at least I make a specific prediction.
If one has a good reputation, you can post whatever you want on the physics pre-print server as Verlinde has. If you have no reputation, you get to keep a real testable hypothesis to yourself until someone with credentials notices. Until then, time to do more calculations in private.

Gravity is wrinkling his face.

From Rio de Janeiro
Carlos

Good article, however one of the crucial descriptive sentences seems
problematic: "Shake the box and it will tend toward nonsense, disorder will increase and information will be lost as the letters shuffle toward their most probable configurations. Could this be gravity? " But the
early universe with its fluctuations was initially largely random, then
over time, "gravity" organized it, right? Or does Verlinde's idea
entail a "thermodynamic imperative" existing because of or
independent of those early fluctuations?

Gravity doesn't exist, well why doesn't everyone jump off the nearest rooftop then? Why does matter have inertia? Does gravity really travel at the speed of light or is it instantaneous? Someone also once said about quantum superposition "when I hear of Schrödinger's cat, I reach for my gun". Theoretical physics has lost its way it appears; it's no longer a science but a cult religion?

At least Einstien's gravity was provable, a practical experiment during an eclipse proved it to bend light. Einstein pretty much said gravity wasn't a force but the curvature of the space-time that permeates the universe. Newton's equations approximate how the curvature behaves. Einstein thought he re-introduced the "ether" in a way, that mystical medium that light traveled through as a wave. We all know to Einstein and other scientists that light and everything pretty much is both a wave and particular. How does gravity increase entropy if it squeezes particles down into generic one square Planck-sized units at a black hole? Isn't that an ultimate ordering of things at a singularity? Gravity would only want to increase entropy if it were stronger at the edges of the universe which it probably is, as the "expanding edges" of the universe is the boundary of a singularity? The universe might be being pulled apart from the outside by gravity? If one looks back in time as they peer out toward the edges of the universe are they not really peering back into the singularity, why it appears so similar in all directions, and why the expansion rate of the universe might seem to be increasing as we peer backward in time? We do know time doesn't exist for electromagnetic radiation and elementary particles? Space isn't really space at all but a seething vacuum of virtual particles that pop into and out of existence so quickly that they disappear before they exist? The universe itself might just be but one vacuum fluctuation out of an infinite number of others?

Many of the above ideas arise from theoretical physics. And many violate a fundamental premise of Quantum Theory that things cannot be known without being observed. Can an unconscious universe really exist then if there is no sentient being there to observe it? Would any sort of culture know if it resided in some experimenter's cosmic Petri dish?

Ya know - I never did buy the in-elegant explanations of gravity. Gravity always came across as a stepchild in an otherwise orderly family of particles and energy. But then, I am not overly fond of describing anything as particles, either. It seems that energy just has many states. Oh, wait - that's thermodynamics, isn't it?

I liked the comment of the person who described the entropic state of the universe as so close to order that why are we so focused on disorder?  I am an earth scientist, not a physicist, but the more I look around me, the more order I see.  It makes sense to me to focus on ORDER to understand everything.  Order is the order of the day!  Disorder is just Pre-order!  Crystals form.  It takes addition of energy to dis-order them.  The universe winds down - therefore, order ensues.  The only exception I can find is when I drag an extension cord around.  It certainly catches on EVERYTHING, including things that I would never have theorized they would catch on.  Of course, this is a form of string theory, so the only conclusion is that having strings dragging all over the place will certainly lead to a state of chaos, but when we stop dragging the strings, we can certainly see where they are caught and unsnarl them.  That is what this physicist needs to do so at least one person can look to see what he is talking about.

Alex # 17:"Will that really increase understanding of the article or lead to a legitimate discussion of the concepts raised?"

Of course it will. For every quip or cogent comment, there are 100's 1000's, 10's of 1000's of eyes pouring over the pages, clicking on the links and hopefully beginning their journey into knowledge. If these comments weren't allowed, we might have the same effect then again, we might not as perhaps 99.9% of people reading it won't understand it(myself included); but with the comments there is an inherent spark that will light the fuse in some reader...one who may not have been interested before, but is now...the chance is too great NOT to offer comments.

Jean # 27:
"God made matter to be attracted to other matter. Could our world perpetuate in any other way?"

As a Christian, I believe God set forth the elements and processes that led to our evolution...and the tools inherent to us are not perfect, we cannot see the full light spectrum without aid, for instance.

Our hearing is limited compared with many other creatures. Just these shortfalls alone should compel you to keep an open mind. Never forget that God put in our hearts the desire to seek him out...by throwing up our hands and saying:
"Ok, we figured it all out. No need to go further.", we actually rob ourselves of the opportunity to know Him; especially when so many questions have yet to be answered. God himself tells us that 'His' time is different than ours. With this in mind how could we possibly be sure we have the answer. If Time, a construct ascribed to our universe, is different for Him, then how much more would 'logic' be? Think of the 'universe' at the molecular level and you get an idea of what I mean.

Our inability to fully comprehend knowledge once it has been obtained(See:Nuclear Energy; Nuclear Weapons)should be proof, even for a Christian such as myself, that we simply cannot assume we have all the answers, regardless of our religious beliefs.

Never fear seeking the truth...God surely can withstand it...
The real question is, can we?
This guy has to get in touch with Al Gore.  I may be mistaken but I believe Al has been working on a similar theory for quite some time.  Al, if you recall, invented Global Warming and the Internet.
Why is there even a comments section for topics like this? So that liberal arts people can quote some irrelevant philosophy and scoff, and blue collar types can go "Get a real job"?

Whether or not they discover it "exists," I have a feeling we're still going to call it "gravity" anyway, just like we still learn Newtonian physics in high school in spite of the fact that it's not a complete picture of how things work.

However, if this research can eventually lead to super techno hyper-drives that can get me to Europe or Asia in like 15 minutes, I'm all for it.

For those questioning the significance of Dr. Verlinde’s ideas, first read up on any current, accepted, verified theories of gravity at the subatomic level (aka quantum gravity). Oh wait, there aren’t any. The search for a suitable quantum theory of gravity has frustrated scientists for years. One of the most recent and best-quality compilations of approaches to quantum gravity is a book entitled Approaches to Quantum Gravity (D. Oriti, ed., Approaches to Quantum Gravity, New York: Cambridge University Press, 2009). Its many contributors are respected physicists with various backgrounds. The book covers current theories and hypotheses, including string theory and its variations, in relation to the problem of gravity. Successes and failures of each theory are explained in detail. One of the book’s main conclusions is that “after 70 years of research in quantum gravity, there is no consensus, and no established theory…There isn’t even a single complete and consistent candidate for a quantum theory of gravity” (pg. 8). This is why scientists like Dr. Verlinde think long and hard about gravity and why any contribution, no matter how trivial it might seem at first, should be explored.

Dr. Verlinde is a respected physicist and has made extraordinary contributions to his field (including a new algebra used in string theory). I believe that even if some of his ideas turn out to be wrong or if they cannot be immediately transformed into a strictly-defined theory, one or more of these “radical” ideas could very well lead us to the consistent theory of subatomic gravity we have been searching for. An entropy approach is as good as any at this point, and is especially interesting considering the statistical nature of subatomic interactions.

The useful and important value of current string theory related to the illusion of gravity is that the technique may have immediate application with only a little engineering and tinkering. Verlinde's idea can be used in the real world, to make real machines and equipment. That is the whole point of the field. Equations and proof are not necessary to begin to work with the method of reasoning, any more than proof of a theory was necessary to make things that used electricity, or understanding the atom was necessary to use chemistry. If Verlinde is correct, then making devices that operate on his ideas is a simple matter of innovative engineering, in which the engineer doesn't need to understand the details of the theory at all.

This is an intriguing article as, of course, is the work that inspired it, but the example of the Gettysburg address was not insightful.

A better example is a sand box. There is only one way to make the sand in the box completely smooth, totally even. But there are many ways to put the sand into piles. (In this analogy, the piles of sand correspond to the starts and planets.) So, it is much more likely to have an uneven sandbox. In the desert as well, sand tends to form large drifts and small ripples.

In a similar way, there is only one way to have a universe where all of the matter is evenly distributed. But there are many ways to make a universe out of stars and planets.

But both analogies are oversimplifications. Strictly speaking, there is more than one way to make the Gettysburg address from a complete set of letters. You could switch around identical letters, switching the two t's in Gettysburg for example. But this does not change the final conclusion. A jumbled box of letters is still much more probable.

For a general discussion, entropy is based on chance. Over a long time, and/or with many events, probability always wins. This is almost a definition. What happens most of the time is by definition the most probable event. But, there is a twist. Very improbable events are very likely to occur at some time. Another was of saying this is, it is very unlikely that extraordinary events NEVER happen.

Concerning the system I propose, it is very unlikely that zillions of photons will converge on a single point at the same time. But if they do, then one can expect the extraordinary.

I really feel badly as a physicist and engineer when I read a comment like, "Newton was wrong ...".

After all,we can and do send people to the moon and get them back using Newton's laws (with a little stuff about the speed of light providing a few rather obvious appropriate ramifications). We can even use our GPS to direct us to Aunt Gwen's house (with a little help from Einstein in keeping our clocks compatible). (Thanks, Mr. Maxwell.)

Thanks, Allan, for allowing us to breathe and, indeed, not fly of into space in spite of these egregious "errors" of past geniuses.
In heat and humidity my hair falls flatter than any note my father tries to sing.  So much for this guy's theory.

What I find interesting about this is how long an incomplete theory can produce predictable results.  Newton and Einstein's understandings of the universe have served us well in science and technology.  Whatever comes next will likely enable more applications.  So is there not then an inherent discrepancy between observation and knowledge?

July 12, 2010

The gravity of this article is in debates in the scientific world established communities with its variant camps.

Ultimately the Nobel Prize quality imprimatur by Royal Stockholm must bestow the immortality on the accepted scientific narratives when the world is ready to for recognition.

The products scientific minds must conform to the top most established Royal societies and without their seals for examination of documented work it really will carry no weight.

This the right way to govern the established matter in one of the four forces of nature and the Standard Model: Gravity, electromagnetism, weak and strong forces?

So unless this work produces a Nobel Prize it is just another on the pile of offerings to the Scientific World.

Let’s see – my bet is that in the camp of String theories without experimental products, that’s demanded by main stream Scientist like for example a Nobel winner Doctor Frank Wilczek than theorizing like Professor Verlinde is best left to the alternate imaginary theoretics that does not nor will not produce any measure in the real science needed at CERN.
All science that does not aid CERN and Nobel prize levels work it just not going to be taken serious and rightfully.

Another problem science author is Doctor Antony Garrett Lisi with his mathematical representational theoretic that is just betting on future CERN products of the Standard Model and is just his gamble that really is not experimental science that he claims is beautiful and right in E8 patterns of the theory of everything. One doesn’t get a Noble Prize for guessing and publishing bravado and in fact is just fun speculation. Science is experimental and observational that is how we want our ideas grounded be it Astrophysics or quantum and those institutions that produce results are deserve the admiration of the world.

Joseph Amato
Manhattan, N. Y.

Well begun is half done, but this does not appear to have " begun".When we touch a live electric wire, we get shock,proof of the phenomenon.Apples continue to fall,proving the phenomenon.Good professor will have to provide such simple proof of non existence of gravity or its source.

I don't wish to discount the possible insight this idea provides. But, I do wonder if sometimes the postulates coming out of theoretical physics are bordering on the philosophical...well, maybe that's not all that bad...

I do appreciate the fact that this gentleman has stated that what he is proposing is not a theory. Rather, I would say that at this point, it is more of "I have a notion..." A theory in the realm of science involves much more rigor than when two guys are drinking beer and one says "I have a theory about that".

Well, thems my random thoughts on this.
If gravity is a push, the universe doesn't suck.
